Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the INFOCOM 2015 Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
IEEE INFOCOM is the premier forum to showcase the latest research outcomes that cover a wide range of topics in communications, data networking and wireless networks. Researchers attend this forum to identify methods of improving their work, and seek feedback from fellow researchers on their work. For students, this is a valuable avenue to interact with other top-tier researchers in very informal and friendly manner. This award will support students at U.S. institutions to attend the 2015 IEEE INFOCOM Conference on Computer Communications which will be held in Hong Kong April 26-May 1, 2015. Priority will be given to students who will benefit from attending this workshop, but are unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding. In addition, applications from female and underrepresented groups in higher education are greatly encouraged.

The requested travel funds will allow graduate students conducting research in the field to attend high-caliber technical presentations, be exposed to state-of-the-art research, and interact with leading researchers and fellow graduate students. The impact to the students' careers from attending INFOCOM 2015 is expected to be substantial, since they would be unable to attend this event without the support of this grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 IEEE INFOCOM Conference on Computer Communications was held in Hong Kong, China from April 26 to May 1, 2015. This preeminent technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of computer communications, and is widely attended by researchers and practitioners in the field. The program consists of technical sessions, workshops, panels, and tutorials. The acceptance rate of INFOCOM 2015 was 19% (typically between 17% and 20% since 2004), which indicates the high quality of the conference. Due to the high volume of submissions from the US, the participation level from US participants was high. 

This project provided funding support to 20 graduate students in the United States to attend this premiere conference. The travel awards has targeted graduate students, in particular, women and underrepresented minority students, since attending conferences is an important part of their educational experience, and they often have limited travel funds. Paper authors have been given priority in consideration, however, having a paper accepted by INFOCOM is not a pre-requisite for receiving the grant. The awards were decided by the award selection committee consisting of two professors, and conflicts-of-interest have been avoided during the selection process.

Participants had the opportunity to present their work, attend panel and keynote sessions, and interact with hundreds of others performing leading-edge research in the field.
